**Chick-fil-A** ([/tʃɪkfɪˈleɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")
[_chik-fil-**AY**_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key"), a [play](/wiki/Play_on_words "Play on
words") on the [American English pronunciation of
"fillet"](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fillet#Pronunciation "wikt:fillet"))
is an American [fast food restaurant](/wiki/Fast_food_restaurant "Fast food
restaurant") chain headquartered in the [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta")
district of [College Park, Georgia](/wiki/College_Park,_Georgia "College Park,
Georgia"), specializing in [chicken sandwiches](/wiki/Chicken_sandwich
"Chicken sandwich").[3][4] Founded in May 1946, it operates more than 2,200
restaurants, primarily in the United States. The restaurant serves breakfast
before transitioning to its lunch and dinner menu. Chick-fil-A also offers
customers catered selections from its menu for special events.[5] Many of the
company's values are influenced by its [founder's](/wiki/S._Truett_Cathy "S.
Truett Cathy") Southern Baptist beliefs;[6] all Chick-fil-A restaurants are
closed for business on Sundays as well as on [Thanksgiving](/wiki/Thanksgiving
"Thanksgiving") and [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas").[6]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

The chain's origin can be traced to the Dwarf Grill (now the Dwarf House), a
restaurant opened by [S. Truett Cathy](/wiki/S._Truett_Cathy "S. Truett
Cathy"), the chain's former chairman and CEO, in 1946. The restaurant is
located in [Hapeville, Georgia](/wiki/Hapeville,_Georgia "Hapeville,
Georgia"), a suburb of Atlanta,[3] and is near the location of the now-
demolished Ford Motor Company [Atlanta Assembly](/wiki/Atlanta_Assembly
"Atlanta Assembly") Plant, for many years a source of many of the restaurant's
patrons.

In 1961, after 15 years in the fast food business, Cathy found a pressure-
fryer that could cook the chicken sandwich in the same amount of time it took
to cook a fast-food hamburger.[7] Following this discovery, he registered the
name Chick-fil-A, Inc. The company's trademarked slogan, _" We Didn't Invent
the Chicken, Just the Chicken Sandwich,"_[8] refers to their flagship menu
item, the Chick-fil-A chicken sandwich.

The first Chick-fil-A opened in 1967, in the food court of the [Greenbriar
Mall](/wiki/Greenbriar_Mall "Greenbriar Mall"), in a suburb of Atlanta.[3]
During the 1970s and early 1980s, the chain expanded by opening new franchises
in suburban malls' food courts.[9] The first freestanding franchise was opened
April 16, 1986, on North Druid Hills Road in Atlanta, Georgia,[10] and the
company began to focus more on this type of franchise than on the food court
type. Although it has expanded outward from its original geographic base, most
new restaurants are located in Southern suburban areas.[3] In October 2015,
the company opened a three-story 5,000-square-foot restaurant in
[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") that became the largest free-standing
Chick-fil-A in the country at that time.[11][12] As of 2016, the chain has
approximately 1,950 locations.[3] It also has 31 [drive-through](/wiki/Drive-
through "Drive-through")-only locations.[3] Chick-fil-A also can be found at
universities, hospitals, and airports through licensing agreements.[3]

Since 1997, the Atlanta-based company has been the title sponsor of the [Peach
Bowl](/wiki/Peach_Bowl "Peach Bowl"), an annual [college
football](/wiki/College_football "College football") bowl game played in
Atlanta on [New Year's Eve](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve "New Year's Eve"). Chick-
fil-A also is a key sponsor of the [SEC](/wiki/Southeastern_Conference
"Southeastern Conference") and the [ACC](/wiki/Atlantic_Coast_Conference
"Atlantic Coast Conference") of college athletics.[13][14]

The company expanded for the first time outside of the United States by
opening an outlet at the [Calgary International
Airport](/wiki/Calgary_International_Airport "Calgary International Airport")
in [Calgary](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary"), Alberta, Canada in May 2014.[15][16]
This restaurant is located near the departure area for flights bound for the
United States.[15] However, per tradition, it is closed Sundays and Christmas
Day.

## Business model[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Business model")]

Chick-fil-A retains ownership of each restaurant. Chick-fil-A selects the
restaurant location and builds it.[17] Chick-fil-A franchisees need only a
$10,000 initial investment to become an operator.[18] Each operator is
handpicked and goes through a rigorous training program; the interviews plus
training can take months and is not an easy process. Chick-fil-A states on
their site:  
  
"This is not the right opportunity for you if you:  
\- Are seeking a passive investment in a business.  
\- Want to sell property to Chick-fil-A, Inc.  
\- Are requesting that Chick-fil-A, Inc. build at a specified location.  
\- Are seeking multi-unit franchise opportunities."  
  
This goes to show how vastly different it is to be a Chick-fil-A store
operator rather than being part of a regular franchise opportunity.[19] Since
2010, Chick-fil-A has led the fast food industry in average sales per
restaurant, despite being open only six days a week,[20] earning an average
$4.8 million per restaurant in 2016 ([Whataburger](/wiki/Whataburger
"Whataburger") was second with $2.7 million per restaurant).[21]

## Advertising[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Advertising")]

"Eat Mor Chikin" is the chain's most prominent advertising slogan, created by
[The Richards Group](/wiki/The_Richards_Group "The Richards Group") in 1995.
The slogan is often seen in advertisements, featuring
[Holstein](/wiki/Holstein_Friesian_cattle "Holstein Friesian cattle") dairy
cows[22] that are often seen wearing (or holding) signs that (usually) read:
"Eat Mor Chikin" in all capital letters. The ad campaign was temporarily
halted during a [mad cow disease](/wiki/Bovine_spongiform_encephalopathy
"Bovine spongiform encephalopathy") scare on January 1, 2004, so as not to
make the chain seem insensitive or appear to be taking advantage of the scare
to increase its sales. Two months later, the cows were put up again. The cows
replaced the chain's old mascot, Doodles, an
[anthropomorphized](/wiki/Anthropomorphic "Anthropomorphic") chicken who still
appears as the C on the logo.[23]

Chick-fil-A vigorously protects its intellectual property, sending [cease and
desist](/wiki/Cease_and_desist "Cease and desist") letters to those they think
have infringed on their trademarks.[24] The corporation has successfully
protested at least 30 instances of the use of an "eat more" phrase, saying
that the use would cause confusion of the public, dilute the distinctiveness
of their intellectual property, and diminish its value.[25]

A 2011 letter to Vermont artist Bo Muller-Moore who [screen
prints](/wiki/Screen_printing "Screen printing") T-shirts reading: "Eat More
Kale" demanded that he cease printing the shirts and turn over his
website.[26] The incident drew criticism from Vermont governor [Peter
Shumlin](/wiki/Peter_Shumlin "Peter Shumlin"), and created backlash against
what he termed Chick-fil-A's "corporate bullying."[27] On December 11, 2014,
Bo Muller-Moore announced that the U.S. Patent Office granted his application
to trademark his "Eat More Kale" phrase. A formal announcement of his victory
took place on December 12, 2014, with Shumlin and other supporters on the
Statehouse steps. His public fight drew regional and national attention, the
support of Shumlin, and a team of pro-bono law students from the University of
New Hampshire legal clinic.[28]

After 22 years with The Richards Group, Chick-fil-A switched to [McCann New
York](/wiki/McCann_Erickson "McCann Erickson") in 2016. Along with the cows,
ads included famous people in history in a campaign called "Chicken for
Breakfast. It's not as crazy as you think."[29]

## Sponsored events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Sponsored events")]

Chick-fil-A Classic

    The Chick-fil-A Classic is a high school basketball tournament held in [Columbia, South Carolina](/wiki/Columbia,_South_Carolina "Columbia, South Carolina").[30] The tournament is in its eighth year of operation and features nationally ranked players, and teams.[31] The tournament is co-sponsored by the Greater Columbia Educational Advancement Foundation (GCEAF), which provides scholarships to high school seniors in the greater Columbia area.

[Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl](/wiki/Peach_Bowl "Peach Bowl")

    The Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl is a college football [bowl game](/wiki/Bowl_game "Bowl game") played each year in [Atlanta, Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia "Atlanta, Georgia").

[Chick-fil-A Kickoff Game](/wiki/Chick-fil-A_Kickoff_Game "Chick-fil-A Kickoff
Game")

    The Chick-fil-A Kickoff Game is an annual early-season college football game played at the [Mercedes-Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium") in Atlanta, Georgia; before 2017, it was played at the [Georgia Dome](/wiki/Georgia_Dome "Georgia Dome"). It features two highly ranked teams, one of which has always been from the Southeastern Conference. In the 2012 season and again in the 2014 season, the event was expanded to two games. It will also be two games in 2017.

[Chick-fil-A Kyle Petty Charity Ride Across America](/wiki/Chick-fil-
A_Kyle_Petty_Charity_Ride_Across_America "Chick-fil-A Kyle Petty Charity Ride
Across America")

    The Chick-fil-A Kyle Petty Charity Ride Across America is an annual charity motorcycle tour to raise money for, among other charities, Victory Junction, a camp for terminally ill children.

## Related restaurants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Related restaurants")]

### The Hapeville Dwarf House[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: The Hapeville Dwarf House")]

Truett Cathy opened his first restaurant, The Dwarf Grill – later renamed the
Dwarf House – in [Hapeville, Georgia](/wiki/Hapeville,_Georgia "Hapeville,
Georgia"), in 1946, and developed the pressure-cooked chicken breast sandwich
there.[3] At the original Chick-fil-A Dwarf Grill, in addition to the full-
size entrances, there is also an extra small-sized front door.[32] The
original Dwarf House in Hapeville, Georgia is open 24 hours a day, six days a
week, except on Sundays, Thanksgiving, and Christmas. The store closes at
10:00 p.m. on Saturday nights, and the day before Thanksgiving and Christmas
and reopens at 6 a.m. on Monday mornings and day after Thanksgiving and
Christmas. It has a larger dine-in menu than the other Dwarf House locations
as well as an animated seven dwarfs display in the back of the restaurant.[32]
It was across the street from the former [Ford Motor
Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company") factory called
[Atlanta Assembly](/wiki/Atlanta_Assembly "Atlanta Assembly").

"Edit section: Dwarf House")]

Truett's original, full-service restaurants offer a substantial menu and
provide customers a choice of table service, walk-up counter service or a
drive-thru window. As of
2012[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit),
13 Chick-fil-A Dwarf House restaurants were operating in the metro Atlanta
area.[3]

### Truett's Grill[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Truett's Grill")]

In 1996, the first Truett's Grill was opened in [Morrow,
Georgia](/wiki/Morrow,_Georgia "Morrow, Georgia"). The second location opened
in 2003 in [McDonough, Georgia](/wiki/McDonough,_Georgia "McDonough,
Georgia"), and a third location opened in 2006 in [Griffin,
Georgia](/wiki/Griffin,_Georgia "Griffin, Georgia").[33] Similar to the Chick-
fil-A Dwarf Houses, these independently owned restaurants offer traditional,
sit-down dining and expanded menu selections in a diner-themed
dinner.[34][35][36] In 2017, Chick-fil-A demolished several Dwarf House
locations to replace them with Truett's Grill locations.[37][38]

## Corporate culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Corporate culture")]

S. Truett Cathy was a devout [Southern Baptist](/wiki/Southern_Baptist
"Southern Baptist"); his religious beliefs had a major impact on the
company.[39] The company's official statement of corporate purpose says that
the business exists "To glorify God by being a faithful steward of all that is
entrusted to us. To have a positive influence on all who come in contact with
Chick-fil-A."[40]

Cathy's beliefs are also responsible for one of the chain's distinctive
features: all Chick-fil-A locations (corporate owned and franchised) are
[closed on Sundays](/wiki/Sunday_shopping "Sunday shopping"),[41] as well as
on [Thanksgiving](/wiki/Thanksgiving_\(United_States\) "Thanksgiving \(United
States\)") and [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas").[42] Cathy states as
the final step in his Five-Step recipe for Business Success "I was not so
committed to financial success that I was willing to abandon my principles and
priorities. One of the most visible examples of this is our decision to close
on Sunday. Our decision to close on Sunday was our way of honoring God and of
directing our attention to things that mattered more than our business."[43]

In an interview with ABC News's _[Nightline](/wiki/Nightline "Nightline")_ ,
Truett's son [Dan T. Cathy](/wiki/Dan_T._Cathy "Dan T. Cathy") told reporter
[Vicki Mabrey](/wiki/Vicki_Mabrey "Vicki Mabrey") that the company is also
closed on Sundays because "by the time Sunday came, he was just worn out. And
Sunday was not a big trading day, anyway, at the time. So he was closed that
first Sunday and we've been closed ever since. He figured if he didn't like
working on Sundays, that other people didn't either." The younger Cathy also
quoted his father as saying, "I don't want to ask people to do that what I am
not willing to do myself."[44]

Their website states, "The Chick-fil-A culture and service tradition in our
Restaurants is to treat every person with honor, dignity and respect
–regardless of their belief, race, creed, sexual orientation or gender."[45]

Chick-fil-A's reputation on being closed on Sundays extends to non-traditional
locations. In addition to countless shopping malls and airports, a Chick-fil-A
location at [Mercedes-Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz
Stadium") in Atlanta will be closed on Sundays despite its main tenant, the
[Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta Falcons"), playing most of
their home games on Sundays. The location will be open when the Falcons have a
[Monday night](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football") or
[Thursday night](/wiki/Thursday_Night_Football "Thursday Night Football") home
game, as well as non-Sunday home games of [Atlanta United
FC](/wiki/Atlanta_United_FC "Atlanta United FC") and other events at the
stadium. On Sundays, the digital signs will be flipped and concessionaire
[Levy Restaurants](/wiki/Levy_Restaurants "Levy Restaurants") will sell
nonbranded food and drinks at the location.[46]

### Same-sex marriage controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Same-sex marriage controversy")]

Main article: [Chick-fil-A same-sex marriage controversy](/wiki/Chick-fil-
A_same-sex_marriage_controversy "Chick-fil-A same-sex marriage controversy")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/PC_Chick-Fil-
A_2012-08-01.jpg/220px-PC_Chick-Fil-A_2012-08-01.jpg)](/wiki/File:PC_Chick-
Fil-A_2012-08-01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PC_Chick-Fil-A_2012-08-01.jpg "Enlarge")

The Chick-fil-A in [Port Charlotte, Florida](/wiki/Port_Charlotte,_Florida
"Port Charlotte, Florida"), on August 1, 2012 "Chick-Fil-A Appreciation Day"

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Chick-fil-
A_Protestors_%28Memphis%29.JPG/220px-Chick-fil-
A_Protestors_%28Memphis%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Chick-fil-
A_Protestors_\(Memphis\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Chick-fil-A_Protestors_\(Memphis\).JPG "Enlarge")

Protestors at [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis,
Tennessee"), Chick-fil-A store on Same Sex Kiss Day

In January 2011, the media reported that Chick-fil-A was co-sponsoring a
marriage conference with the Pennsylvania Family Institute (PFI), an
organization that has opposed [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage
"Same-sex marriage") legislation.[47][48][49][50][51] Chick-fil-A clarified
that "one of our independent Restaurant Operators in Pennsylvania was asked to
provide sandwiches to two Art of Marriage video seminars".[52] The [WinShape
Foundation](/wiki/WinShape_Foundation "WinShape Foundation"), a charitable
organization founded by Truett and his wife, also stated that it would not
allow same-sex couples to participate in its marriage retreats.[53]

Chick-fil-A has donated over $5 million, via WinShape, to groups that oppose
same-sex marriage. Of this, more than $3 million was donated primarily to
Christian organizations whose agendas included positions that oppose same-sex
marriage,[54] with the money donated between 2003 and
2009.[55][56][57][58][59][60][61][62] A total of $1.9 million was donated in
2010 to groups such as the Marriage & Family Foundation, [Exodus
International](/wiki/Exodus_International "Exodus International"), and the
[Family Research Council](/wiki/Family_Research_Council "Family Research
Council") (FRC).[63] That year, the FRC, which received
$1,000[55][56][57][58][59][60][61][62] was listed as an anti-gay[64] [hate
group](/wiki/Hate_group "Hate group") by the [Southern Poverty Law
Center](/wiki/Southern_Poverty_Law_Center "Southern Poverty Law
Center").[65][66][67] WinShape has also contributed to Christian groups
including the [Fellowship of Christian
Athletes](/wiki/Fellowship_of_Christian_Athletes "Fellowship of Christian
Athletes") and [Exodus International](/wiki/Exodus_International "Exodus
International"), the latter is noted for supporting ex-gay [conversion
therapy](/wiki/Conversion_therapy "Conversion therapy").[63] In response,
students at several colleges and universities worked to ban or remove the
company's restaurants from their campuses. On January 28, 2013, Shane L.
Windmeyer, the leader of [Campus Pride](/wiki/Campus_Pride "Campus Pride"),
suspended their campaign.[68][69][70]

In June and July 2012, Chick-fil-A's [chief operating
officer](/wiki/Chief_operating_officer "Chief operating officer") Dan T. Cathy
made several public statements about same-sex marriage, saying that those who
"have the audacity to define what marriage is about" were "inviting God's
judgment on our nation".[71][72][73][74][75] Several prominent politicians
expressed disapproval.[76] [Boston Mayor](/wiki/Boston_Mayor "Boston Mayor")
[Thomas Menino](/wiki/Thomas_Menino "Thomas Menino") and [Chicago
Alderman](/wiki/Chicago_Alderman "Chicago Alderman") [Proco "Joe"
Moreno](/wiki/Proco_Joe_Moreno "Proco Joe Moreno") said they hoped to block
franchise expansion into their areas.[77][78][79] The proposed bans drew
criticism from liberal pundits, legal experts, and the [American Civil
Liberties Union](/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union "American Civil
Liberties Union").[80][81][82] The [Jim Henson
Company](/wiki/Jim_Henson_Company "Jim Henson Company"), which had a
_[Pajanimals](/wiki/Pajanimals "Pajanimals")_ kids' meal toy licensing
arrangement with Chick-fil-A, said it would cease its business relationship,
and donate the payment to the [Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against
Defamation](/wiki/Gay_%26_Lesbian_Alliance_Against_Defamation "Gay & Lesbian
Alliance Against Defamation").[83][84][85] Chick-fil-A stopped distributing
the toys, claiming that unrelated safety concerns that had arisen prior to the
controversy.[86] Chick-fil-A released a statement on July 31, 2012, saying,
"We are a restaurant company focused on food, service, and hospitality; our
intent is to leave the policy debate over same-sex marriage to the government
and political arena."[87]

#### Response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Response")]

In response to the controversy, former [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas")
Governor [Mike Huckabee](/wiki/Mike_Huckabee "Mike Huckabee") initiated a
Chick-fil-A Appreciation Day movement to counter a [boycott](/wiki/Boycott
"Boycott") of Chick-fil-A launched by same-sex marriage activists.[88][89][90]
More than 600,000 people RSVPed on [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") for
Huckabee's appreciation event.[89] On August 1, Chick-fil-A restaurants
experienced a large show of public support across the nation with the company
reporting record-breaking sales.[88][89][90] A consulting firm estimated that
the average Chick-fil-A restaurant had 29.9 percent more sales and 367 more
customers than it did on a typical Wednesday.[18]

#### Report of policy change[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-
fil-A&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Report of policy change")]

In September 2012, [The Civil Rights Agenda](/wiki/The_Civil_Rights_Agenda
"The Civil Rights Agenda") (TCRA) announced that Chick-fil-A had "ceased
donating to organizations that promote discrimination, specifically against
LGBT civil rights." Chick-fil-A officials did state in an internal document
that they "will treat every person equally, regardless of sexual
orientation."[91] In a letter from Chick-fil-A's Senior Director of Real
Estate, the company states, "The WinShape Foundation is now taking a much
closer look at the organizations it considers helping, and in that process
will remain true to its stated philosophy of not supporting organizations with
political agendas."[92][93]

According to Chicago [Alderman](/wiki/Alderman "Alderman") [Proco "Joe"
Moreno](/wiki/Proco_Joe_Moreno "Proco Joe Moreno"), Chick-fil-A has a
statement of respect for all people regardless of [sexual
orientation](/wiki/Sexual_orientation "Sexual orientation") in an internal
document called _Chick-fil-A: Who We Are_. A document released by Chick-fil-A
on September 20, 2012, does not mention any organizations opposed to same-sex
marriage as being part of Chick-fil-A's donation base. WinShape Marriage will
continue to be supported financially, with a stated focus on couple retreats
to strengthen marriages.[94]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Chick-fil-A_-
_Hillsboro%2C_Oregon.jpg/220px-Chick-fil-A_-
_Hillsboro%2C_Oregon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chick-fil-A_-_Hillsboro,_Oregon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chick-fil-A_-_Hillsboro,_Oregon.jpg "Enlarge")

Chick-fil-A in [Hillsboro, Oregon](/wiki/Hillsboro,_Oregon "Hillsboro,
Oregon")

According to [Focus on the Family](/wiki/Focus_on_the_Family "Focus on the
Family")'s website, _CitizenLink.com_ , "Chick-fil-A and its charitable-giving
arm, the WinShape Foundation, did not agree to stop making donations to groups
that support the Biblical definition of marriage in exchange for being allowed
to open a franchise in Chicago."[95] Mike Huckabee stated that he "talked
earlier today personally with Dan Cathy, CEO of Chick Fil-A about the new
reports that Chick Fil-A had capitulated to demands of the supporters of same
sex marriage. This is not true. The company continues to focus on the fair
treatment of all of its customers and employees, but to end confusion gave me
this statement." The statement provided by Chick-fil-A was posted on
Huckabee's website.[96][97]

## Recipe changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Recipe changes")]

Though Chick-fil-A has always used [trans-fat](/wiki/Trans-fat "Trans-fat")
free processes in its chicken sandwiches, anticipating the dietary concerns of
consumers, in 2008, it became the first fast-food restaurant to become
completely trans-fat free.[98]

In 2011, food blogger and activist [Vani Hari](/wiki/Vani_Hari "Vani Hari")
wrote a post titled "Chick-fil-A or Chemical Fil-A?" on her website,
FoodBabe.com. She noted that Chick-fil-A sandwiches contained nearly 100
ingredients, including [peanut oil](/wiki/Peanut_oil "Peanut oil") with
[TBHQ](/wiki/TBHQ "TBHQ").[99] In October 2012, Chick-fil-A invited Hari to
meet with company executives at its [Atlanta, GA](/wiki/Atlanta,_GA "Atlanta,
GA") headquarters.[100] In December 2013, Chick-fil-A notified Hari that it
had eliminated the [dye Yellow No. 5](/wiki/Tartrazine "Tartrazine") and had
reduced the [sodium](/wiki/Salt "Salt") content in its chicken soup. The
company also said that it is testing a peanut oil that does not contain TBHQ
and that it would start testing sauces and dressings made without [high-
fructose corn syrup](/wiki/High_fructose_corn_syrup "High fructose corn
syrup") in 2014.[100]

## Plan to raise its chickens without
antibiotics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Chick-fil-A&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Plan to raise its chickens without antibiotics")]

According to the [Food and Drug
Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug
Administration"), antibiotics used in livestock, many of which are also used
to treat humans, have contributed to the rise of dangerous bacteria. In
December 2012, the FDA announced plans to phase out certain antibiotics in the
food production industry.[101]

In February 2014, Chick-fil-A announced plans to serve chicken raised without
antibiotics in its restaurants nationwide within five years. Chick-fil-A is
the first quick service restaurant to set forth a plan and commit to serving
only poultry raised without antibiotics.[102]
